sentences.english: This is the second time I have been let down by you, I shall never trust you again .
sentences.chinese: 我已是第二次被你拆台了，我再也不相信你了。

sentences.english: Are you suggesting we start slashing each other's throats?
sentences.chinese: 那么你建议我们现在就开始互相拆台？

sentences.english: Team work as glory, Mutual hurt as shame.
sentences.chinese: 以团结协作为荣，以彼此拆台为耻。

sentences.english: Kennedy handled the firestorm of outrage with self-defeating smugness.
sentences.chinese: 肯尼迪用自我拆台的自命不凡来对付愤怒的烈火。

definition: to be a drag or hindrance on sb
lit. to sing a duet/fig. to collaborate with sb/also used satirically: to play second fiddle to
to throw stones at sb who fell down a well (idiom); to hit a person who is down
to sow dissension (idiom); to drive a wedge between
(dialect) dirty/to mock sb
to play dirty tricks/to be up to mischief
to lie through one's teeth (idiom)/to talk drivel
lit. to point at the mulberry tree and curse the locust tree/fig. to scold sb indirectly/to make oblique accusations (idiom)
to pick fault with/to spot the differences/to nitpick/to pick a quarrel/to find complaint with
to echo one another (idiom)
(coll.) to mock/to bully/to force (a concession out of sb)
to watch with amusement as sb makes a fool of himself
to undermine/to let someone down/to seduce someone away from something
to try to smooth things over/to paper over the issues/to gloss things over
to be put on the spot/to find oneself in an awkward situation
to bicker/to argue for the sake of arguing/to carry on poles (together with sb else)/to carry a coffin on poles
